editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

The Eunuch begins on verso of F2 [i.e. E2].

div.head: The argument according to Muretus' collection.
div.p:
There were two brothers citizens of Athens, the one called Chremes the other Phania. Chremes being to travel into Asia left the charge of his then only daughter Basibula an infant with his brother Phania. Shortly after his departure out of Attica, Phania also to avoid the rage of war growing hot in Greece, shipped himself thence with his little niece, directing his course towards the place where he supposed Chremes abode: but suffering shipwreck was cast with the little one, upon the shore of the isle of Andros, where getting entertainment of a poor islander he shortly after died. His host after his decease, changeth the child's name from Pasibula into Glycerium; and having bred her up for some years in equal education with his own natural child called Chrysis, himself also dyeth. Chremes in the interim had returned to Athens, and there had another daughter named Philumena: and all this while supposed his brother and his other daughter to have long since perished at sea. Chrisis being left fatherless and poor leaves Andros, and taking Glycerium with her sails to Athens; where they dwell together as reputed sisters. Chrisis turns harlot: her lovers draw along with them to her house one Pamphilus' son of Simo an ancient Athenian citizen. Pamphilus falling in love with Glycerium gets her with child, and affianceth
himself to her. Chremes upon a public fame of Pamphilus his virtues treats with Simo for a match between their children Pamphilus and Philumena: and a marriage is agreed upon between the two old fathers, Pamphilus being not made acquainted. Chrysis soon after dies, at whose funerals Pamphilus occasionally discovered signs of very ardent affection to Glycerium; which Chremes hearing of, renounceth him for son in law as one apparently besotted and entangled with extraordinary love to a straggling strumpet (So ignorantly he styled the issue of his proper loins) Pamphilus (Now first hearing of the determined match) is glad such marriage is disappointed. Simo frets at it. And now is the prefixed day of marriage come, being the day containing the argument of this comedy. Simo makes show to all the people of his family, as if the marriage were on this day to be solemnised, and this he did out of a foxlike subtlety to feel his son's inclination to marriage, and upon his refusal to have just occasion of complaint against him, which hitherto he had not. And if his son should declare readiness to entertain the match, he then thought it would prove no such difficult matter to overrule Chremes; and so the business to go on as it was first determined. Simo having thus projected matters, meets his son; and wills him to pray to the gods for success upon his marriage instantly to be accomplished. The son at his father's salutation stands thunderstrucken, ignorant what course to take for prevention. Davus comes to him in this distraction, at what time one Charinus was with him. This Charinus was a young man inflamed with the love of Philumena, the intended bride; and was now in a manner desperate, when he understood that Pamphilus was that day to marry her: Pamphilus assures him of his purposed resolution to the contrary. This was the theme of their discourse when Davus came upon them. Davus (Now) was Simoes' servant, a fellow
of good reach: and he upon grounds reasonable had conceived his old master's fetch in this pretended marriage, which (Having sent away Charinus) he opens to Pamphilus: resolving him that in all likelihood the old man did but cast out a hook to catch at his inclination to Glycerium: wishing him therefore without all scruple to promise his father all obedience and readiness in embracing this faced marriage; he further intimates, that no hazard was likely hereby to ensue: for that Chremes having once openly refused him, would not (At least so suddenly) entertain him for a son in law. Pamphilus puts the advice in execution. Simo and Davus venture either of them upon the hazard, but Simo his luck carries it. For Chremes is won to a new consent, and now is Pamphilus in danger to be cast upon a present marriage, where he never intended. What may Davus how do? author of a counsel not so unlikely as unlucky? Chance presents him occasion, and he hath good brain to make use of the least offered occasion: what is that? Glycerium is brought to bed: the new born child is by her maid, but by Davus' direction) laid at Simo's door: and this is done just when Chremes must of necessity see it: Davus further so carries the matter, that Chremes understands who is father, who is mother to the child. These things justly moan Chremes to a second renunciation: hence great stirie ariseth: Crito a man of Andros (Arrived at Athens upon news of crisis her death, being next heir to her estate) ends all; by discovering Glycerium's freedom and parentage. Pamphilus marries Glycerium now again known by her first name Pasibula; Charinus marries the other sister Philumena.

div.head: The actors and their characters.
div.p: Simo an old man careful of his son, whom he loved at first for his reported virtues: and after he once doubted his carriage, showed his greater love in his care of him. In the first seen he carries himself mild in discourse and behaviour: and still after increaseth in angry mood, till at length he grows to rage and passion.
Pamphilus. Son to Simo, a well qualified young man and faithful lover.
Davus servant of the family, subtle wife, confident.
Dromo. Another servant, only used for Davus' punishment.
Sosia. Snno's freedman, a protatic person brought in only, to whom the ground of the argument might be opened.
Chremes. an old man of a quiet and tranquil spirit.
Glycerium. Daughter of Chremes not presented on the stage; neither speaks but within doors in labour of childbirth:
Charinus. A young man, simple and ignorant.
Byrrhia. His man for wit above his master. Discreet.
Crito. A stranger of Andros, poor yet honest, wise and of a good spirit and stomach.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: Our poet first setting his mind to write,
Deemed this the sole main charge upon him laid,
To please the people with the plays he made:
But now he finds that he misreckoned quite.
For, that he cannot (Prologue wise) now lay
The argument of this his play aright,
Is caused by an old rancorous poet's spite;
Who drutes him to clear faults, leave the meant way.
Now pray observe their cauellings: those plays
Andria and Perinthia, which Menander wrote,
(Know one, know both) not much unlike in plot,
Are different yet both in their style and phrase.
He not denies that from Perinthia
Those things which seemed convenient in the same,
He (As his own) hath drawn into the frame,
And course of this presented Andria.
This is the thing they challenge: and they brawl
That in such sort a cleanly comedy
Should not be hotch-potched. These men verily
While much they seem, show they know naught at all:
Who him accusing draw his presidents
Navius, Plautus, Ennius, in like crime,
To whose mistakings he would rather climb,
Then follow these men's obscure diligence.
I further wish 'em hence forth keep 'em still;
And cease with evil language him to sting;
Lest their ill doing in their ears do ring.
Spectators kind, of you we crave good will;
In silence shown and kind attention;
That without prejudice our play you'd hear:
Thence you may fully know, if it rest clear,
That all our future purposed action
Of new made plays be to be banished quite;
Without adventuring your hereafter sight:

div.head: Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Simo and Sosia with two or three seruanes more bearing provision from the market.

sp.speaker: Simo.
sp.p: Ye sirs have those things in: away I say.

sp.speaker: Sosia
sp.p: Draw near; I am to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: I think th'errand given;
Your meaning is
I look to those things careful cookery.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Pray say on
What 'tis, my art may further do for you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Here's need of no such art, in what I purpose;
But of those parts which I have ever noted
To dwell in thee; trust, and true secrecy.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Since I bought thee first
Being then a youngling, in what gentle sort,
In what due course, thou ledst thy service with me,
Thyself well knowest: and for I found thee careful
In thy employments, the best good I had
To answer it, I gave thee; liberty.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 is my heart's joy master, if I did
Or 〈◊〉 can do, ought to your satisfaction;
And further owe you thanks that you acknowledge
I well accepted: yet it troubles me,
For this remembrancing your benefit,
Seems to upbraid me, as forgetting it.
Pray in one word acquaint me with your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will; but first I tell thee of this thing,
This which thou thinkst is no meant marriage.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.p: Why make you as it were then?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thou shalt hear
From the beginning all: and by that means
Shalt better know my son's forepast life,
My present purpose, and thy future charge.
My son having passed his childhood Sosia
Hath now more scope allowed him; before
How could one know or fist his disposition,
While tender age, fear, tutors awed him?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What almost all youth do,
To set their mind on one some chosen course;
That to breed hearse, this hounds, and both to hunt,
A third to study of philosophy:
He none of these followed professedly,
Above the rest: but yet all moderately.
I joyed at it.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Sir, not without good cause:
"For to o'erdo no one thing, in my sense
" to man's life is of chiefest consequence.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Such his behaviour; all those gently
To bear and forbear, that he kept withal;
Apply himself to please and humour all;
Cross none, nor proudly seek to overtop
His young companions: so that easily
He got him friends and praise; yet without envy.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: He bore him wisely: for in this times state
Sweet yielding procures friends; blunt truth gets hate.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Meanwhile a certain woman three years since
Drawn by her wants and kindred's negligence,
From Anaros isle came to our neighbourhood;
Of passing beauty, flouring womanhood.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.p: I fear this Andrian woman bodes no good.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She at the first a sparing chaste life led;
At rock and loom, hard laboured to get bread:
But when a first, a second, a third came;
Tendering their loves, gifts promised with the same,
(As all our natures are prone commonly
From labour unto wanton liberty)
She stooped to lure, began the gainful trade.
By those that then chief love unto her made,
My son was drawn along occasionally
To banquet with 'em; keep 'em company.
I to myself — sure the young fry is ta'en:
Has catched the poisoned bait; with it, his bane.
These lovers servants passing to and fro
I every morning watch; and calling to
One that I spied, thus question; prithee lad,
Who yesterday yond Chrysis company had?
So was the Andrian called.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: The answer was, Phoedrus, or Nicerate,
Or Clinias (For at that time those three
Her jointly loved.) I reply presently,
And what did Pamphilus? what? (Answers he.)
He staked his share, and supped: this gladded me.
At other times I cast more news to learn;
Still nothing found that did my son concern.
I thought him now proof-tempered 'gainst excess,
Great pattern of a settled staidness.
For he that deals with natures of this kind,
Yet thereby grows not staggering in his mind;
To such a man's own hands thou mayst be bold
To leave the free reigns of his life in hold.
As this gave me most satisfying pleasure,
So all tongues talked my good, proclaimed my treasure,
In having such a qualified son.
What should I make further relation?
Chremes our neighbour drawn by this same bruit,
Freely comes to me; and makes earnest suit
To place his daughter, yea his only one
With a large dowry as wife unto my son:
I agreed the marriage, on his motion;
And this the day, it is appointed on.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: What barie now stoppeth? why in very deed
According to the show, it not proceed?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll tell thee: few days after this befell,
Our neighbour Chrysis died.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: That's chanced well.
You have revived me; I much doubted her.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: With Chrysis lovers still my son comes there
Alike her funeral looks to; alike cheer
Sometimes of sadness shows, sometimes alike
Weeps with 'em: I his carriage well did like
Thus argued I; her death how tenderly
For very small acquaintance doth he take?
What, if himself had loved her? what for me,
What will he do for me, his father's sake?
All this I thought in my simplicity,
Merely the functions of humility,
And of kind heart. Why lengthen I my tale?
Myself for his sake tend the funeral.
Dreaming as yet no evil.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll cause thee know. The dead corpse is brought out;
Along we go; now there amid the throng
Of wanton, I a maiden very young
Perchance espied; of person —

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ay, and of countenance Sosia so delightsome,
So modest, fair, that nothing might her stain:
Who for she seemed to me, in all the train
Most to lament; and was above the rest
Of sweet and comely personage and face.
I pressed near to the maids, asked what she was:
They told me Chrysis sister. Instantly
It struck me cold at heart. O God! thought I,
Hence grew his tears: his tenderness she breeds.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.p: How I do fear whither your tale proceeds.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: The funeral goes on: we attend the same
To th'sepulchre she's come: into the flame
She's put: all weep. The maid I named late
Approached the fire, as careless, desperate;
To her evident danger: here my frighted son
Well shown his long concealed affection
So close dissembled: to her hies he fast,
And both his arms folding about her waist,
My dear Glycerium says he, how dost? say,
What cause hast thou to make thyself away?
Then she (That all their endeared love might spy)
Cast herself on him, weeping tenderly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Home I get me straight,
Enraged and fretting; yet no cause of weight
Appeared to me to chide him: he might plead,
What foul fact have I done? what merited?
Or wherein faulted, father? one that sought
To burn herself, I hindered (As I ought)
And saved her life. It were a fair reply.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: You weigh things well; for if deservedly
He may be chidden which helped life to save,
Who hurts or spoils one, what should that man have?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Next day comes Chremes to me, urging thus,
O case to be lamented! Pamphilus
(I find clear) holds yond stranger harlotry
In place of a just wife: this earnestly
I do deny, he stiffly holds. In fine,
I so part with him, as one utterly
Denies to give his daughter to my son.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nor yet I saw
A grounded cause to build a chiding on.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thus my son might urge his law:
Yourself sir set a limitation
To this my course: the time is coming on,
I must myself to another's will apply:
Let me ath' interim mine own satisfy.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.p: For what cause then of blaming will you 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: If for loose love he shall dome to marry
That is the first occasion that I seek
Against him; and the present way I make
By this self marriage, if he show mislike
Is hereby true pretence of blame to take.
Besides, if wicked Davus have a foot
Any contrivement, that he now consume
His stock of knavery whilst it cannot hurt
Who (I imagine) tooth and nail will practise,
And that with purpose rather to cross me
Then please my son.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Makest thou a question? evil minds, ill manners.
Whom if in any thing I shall discover —
But what need talk? if happily it fall
(As I do wish) my son be nothing backward,
It only rests, that I persuade with Chremes:
Which I hope may be wrought. Now, be't your charge
Well to bear up this seeming marriage;
Fright Davus; observe my son's carriage;
And note their consultations.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.p: 'Tis enough; I'll see to 't: shall we in.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Go before, I follow.
There is no question, my son would decline
This marriage; that I marked in Davus' sear,
When he had heard that wedding did go forward.
But he himself comes forth.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I mar'ld if this would end so, and still doubted
Whereto my masters caline remissness tended:
Who when he saw his son could have no wife,
Never made word to us on't; nor gave sign
Of being troubled at it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now he will
Talk to you on't; and as I do suppose
To your no little cost.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: This was his cunning,
To lead us on in fair fools paradise;
And in our secure dreaming take us napping,
Having no time to cast prevention.
A fox i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What is't the knave talks on?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: What now trow is in working?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Dost thou demand that?
Folks talk my son's in love.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: That by’r lady
Concerns the world to think on.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Dost mark me
In what I say or not?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: But now of this for me to make inquiry
Were no kind father's part. What hitherto
Has done, I pass not: while the time permitted
I gave him way to take his course and pleasures:
His years now call for a new life, new manners.
Henceforward Davus I require, or rather
(If the word may befit me) I request thee,
Retrieve my son from this loose liberty.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: All these loose libertines
That wantonly do love, cannot endure
To hear of wiving.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Beside, if such one chance to light upon
Some patron of his inclination,
His raw green sickly mind he commonly
Wonts to the worser part still to apply.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Troth sir I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: No verily: I am your plain man Davus;
No riddle-teller, cunning Oedipus.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou'dst then in plain terms have me speak my mind?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Yes, pray at any hand sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: If I find
That thou today use any cunning crotchet,
Whereby to hinder this intended wedding;
Or fain wouldst show thy wits fine nimbleness:
When I have first well whipped thee, in the mill
I'll thrust thee, to thy very dying day:
With this proviso and condition,
If ever I thence free thee, I'll grind for thee.
What, understandest me yet, or not yet neither?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Yes clearly now; you've used no round-abouts,
But come to th' matter roundly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: In ought else
Save this, I better could endure a slighting.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Makest thou a jest on't?
I know thee to a hair: but I do tell thee,
Lest thou shouldst rashly venture. Do not say
But thou'st had fair warning given thee: look to't.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Upon my faith now Davus here's no leisure
Left thee, to rest or dream upon the matter;
For ought I gather of the old man's purpose
Touching this wedding. which not wisely holpen
Me or young master undoes utterly.
Not can I judge my best course, him to succour,
Or lean to the old man's counsel: forsake him?
I doubt his life; assist him? th'other's threats;
Whom to o'er reach it's hard. First has discovered
All of their love: then keeps hard watch o'er me,
Lest I should lead some trumping card in th'way:
Which if he find, I'm lost: or else at pleasure
He'll take occasion, be it right, be it wrong;
And to the mill I shall be tumbled headlong.
To all these hazards comes another mischief:
This Andrian woman, be she his wife, or leman,
Is great with child by him. Now, 'tis worth nothing
To hear their bold adventure: none can judge it
Fond lover's fancy, but mere frenzy rather:
For whether boy or girl she shall bring forth,
They have resolved to keep and nourish it.
Besides they coin a pretty cunning fable,
Among themselves, that she's free Attic born.
There was long since (Say they) an ancient merchant
Shipwrecked on Andros island; who there died;
And that with him then saved, Chrysis father
Took up a little girl. Conceited fiction!
To me it seems unlikely: yet they soothe
Themselves ith' tale. But see Mysis comingEnter mysis.
From out Glycerium's house. I'll to the market
To seek out Pamphilus: for fear his father
Unwates do press him with this business. Exit Dauus.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: Good God Archillis, I do hear you woman:
You would have lesbia fetched; upon my word
She is a drunken gossip, and unheedy:
And one scarce fit to whom you may commit
A woman in first childbirth: yet he fetch her.
Note you the old ones importunity!
None but her pot companion will serve turn.
But I pray God grant this a good delivery:
And that the midwife rather may elsewhere
Neglect, than here. But what may be the cause
I Pamph 'Us see so much disquieted?
I fear what it may be. I'll stay a while
To know the reason of his troubled gesture.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Is this kind dealing? courteous attempt?
Is this a father's carriage?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: O gods and men your faith! what can be said,
Neglect, disgrace, or scorn, if this be none?
Say he had meant to marry me today;
Ought I not have foreknown it? ought I not
Have been made privy to it?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: Out alas,
Wretch that I am, what do I hear him talk of?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What should I think of Chremes? who denied
To trust me as a husband with his daughter?
Changeth he mind, because I rest unchanged?
That he should still thus obstinately endeavour
Me most accursed to divorce and sever
From my Glycertam? which, if it fall out,
I am undone for ever. Amongst men
Was ever yet found out one more disgraceful?
More every way unhappy than myself?
Men, gods assist me! is there left no way
For me to shun Chremes affinity?
How many ways have I been scorned? refused?
(All done, all ended) the other day cast of
Ain now again required: and why so?
Unless (I guess) h'has some deformed piece,
Which when he cannot fasten upon any,
He seeks to 〈◊〉 on me?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: This talk of his
Kills me poor wretch with sear.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: For what should I
Now of my father speak? O God! that he
So weighty a thing should do so carelessly.
Passing now by me in the marketplace,
Go, get you home, says he; and fit yourself:
This day you must be married Pamphilus.
To me his words seemed of such sound and sense,
As he had said, get home and hang thyself.
I stood confounded at it. Do you think
I had a word to utter? any excuse?
Though foolish, false, unfitting? I stood dumb.
Yet had I known't afore, what could I do?
If any now should ask me, I would surely
Use other course, then (As I did) keep silence.
But now what first thing shall I enter on?
So many cares, several distraction,
Puzzles my mind: love, pity of her, fear
About this marriage so loathed, so near:
Then the respect I owe my father, who
So mildly hath me suffered hitherto
Without restraint to run my own free race,
In every course I listed: with what face
May I now cross his pleasure? wretched me!
I know not what to rest on.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: I poor woman
Doubt th'end of this irresolution.
But now 'tis very needful that I draw him
To speak with her; or else of her
Find some discourse to him. Whilst yet his mind
Hangs wavering, every little moment turns it.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Who is't talks hereabout? Mysis well met.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: How does she? marry sir in pangs of travail:
And many troublous thoughts come in her mind
About this day, once purposed for your wedding.
She further doubts, lest you may mind to leave her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: May I be thought to mind a thing so foul?
And through my fault suffer mine own dear soul
To be abused? trusting her heart, her life
To me? whom I have made my dearest wife?
May I permit her chaste well trained mind
Enforced by foul want to change it kind?
No, I will never do it.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: If it lay
In you, I need not fear: but how you may
Be forced by your father, is the doubt.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What Mysis dost thou think me such a love?
So ingrateful further? so inhumane, bestial?
That nor acquaintance, love, or shame, at all
May move or prompt me to keep plighted faith?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: One thing I know, that she deserved hath
That you should mind her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Should mind her Mysis?
Even now the very latest words of Chrysis
Touching Glycerium, rest imprinted here;
Here at my heart. Her last hour drawing near,
She called for me: I came to her: all you
Voided the room: being alone we two
She thus began. Kind Pamphilus you see
Glycerium's youth and beauty; verily
Two weak unsafe guards (As yourself perceive)
To keep her chaste, guard the small stock I leave.
Wherefore by this right hand I crave of thee,
By thy good nature, thy fidelity:
I adjure thee by her here unfriendedness
Thou wouldst not leave her: do not part from her.
If as a brother I thee still respected,
If she of all men hath thee best affected,
As she in all things sought thy full contentment
In true observance, due obedience.
I leave thee as a friend, a guardian, father,
A husband to her. All the little wealth
I leave behind, I trust to thy disposing.
Then her hand taking, in my hand she clasped it;
And forthwith died. I then there received her;
Received will keep.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: But why dost now come from her?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: I am sent
To fetch the midwife.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: O, I prithee hasten.
And hear you? see you mention not a word
About the marriage: lest it may perhaps
Add to her weakness.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.stage: Exeunt Pamphilus and Mysis several ways.

div.head: Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Charinus and Byrrhia his man.

sp.speaker: Cha
sp.l: What sayest thou Byrrhia? must she then today
Be married unto Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.l: But e'en very now
Davus so told me in the marketplace.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Accursed, wretched me! how hitherto
My thoughts have waited upon hope and fear?
But hope now being fled, my fainting spirits
Wasted with care, yield to confusion.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.l: Pray, for god's love Charinus, since that things
Cannot be as you would, seek to desire
What you may compass.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: There is nothing else
In all the world I wish, but Philumen.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.l: But how much better were it, to endeavour
To unlodge this idle love out of your heart,
Then thus to talk of that which adds more fuel
To this your bootless vain affection?
sp.stage: Enter Pamphilus walking in a dump.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: All men in health can easily prescribe
To the sick patient good directions.
If thou wert in my case thy mind would alter.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: Well sir then do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: But lo yonder
Where Pamphilus is. I do mean to venture
All trials yet, ere I do fully perish.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: What means he now to do?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I will request,
Beseech him, open to him all my love.
I hope I may obtain of him at least,
For some few days to put the wedding of.
I trust in th'interim somewhat may be done.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Byrrhia,
What think'st thou of it? shall I go to him?

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.l: What else? if he will yield to nothing, yet
Let him suspect, you have good mind to horn him
If he shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Away lience varlet,
With this thy lewd suspicion.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Charinus,
God save you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: And you also Pamphilus.
I was a coming to you, with desire
To crave hope, help, health, counsel at your hands.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Troth I have neither place for counsel left,
Nor means to help. but what's the matter man?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If you do Pamphilus, I can assure you,
This is the last day you shall ever see me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I shame to tell it, Birrhia prithee
Declare the matter to him.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: Sir, he loves your wife that shall be.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Troth he and I are of two several minds:
I can assure thee. Prithee harken hither
Charinus; hast not had to do with her
More, than thy man here talks of.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Pamphilus,
No o'my troth. I am. O, how I wish thou hadst.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Now I entreat thee by our friendship, love;
First that you would not marry her at all.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If't full so,
You cannot shun it, or do else affect it —

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Yet defer it of awhile,
That I may void hence somewhere, and not see't.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Charinus, now hear me. I do not think't
At any time a part of honesty,
When one deserves naught, to expect for thanks.
I'd rather shun this match than thou obtain't.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: You put new life into me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: If thou canst now,
Or this this thy man here; work, invent, fashion,
Take all the course you can to make her thine:
I will find means, that mine she shall not be.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: And in good time I see
Danus, whose counsel I rely upon.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: But thou dull head canst nothing cast about
Worth knowing. Can you leave us?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Good God! what good news bring I?
But where●row may I find Pamphilus out?
To end his fears, and fill his heart with comfort.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: He is jocund, at what I know not.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Tut, man, 'tis, nothing.
The mischief now afoot, he yet not hears of.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Who if he have heard of this prepared wedding —

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I guess verily
Hunts all the town o'er for me, like a madman.
But where shall I look for him? to what place
First bend my course?

sp.speaker: Cha
sp.p: Why speak you not unto him?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I'll get me hence, and seek him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Davus, stay:
Come hither.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Who is't calls? O Pamphilus,
I sought you: you here too Charinus? brave.
Both in the nick. You're the men, I looked for.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: My life now lies at stake.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: You weary me
With news, that I am perfect in already.
You fear to have her; you to miss her.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Well, and I say the point
Has then no danger in it. Observe me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: For god's sake rid me quickly of this fear.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Lo, I fice thee. Chremis now's not minded
To trouble you with a wife.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Your father took me by the sleeve e'en now,
And told me this day he would marry you:
Adding much more, which now's no time to talk on.
Presently hastening to acquaint you with it,
I ran to the marketplace: there missing you
I got to a high raised ground, and round about
Looked to espy you; could not. Then by chance
I saw Charinus servant, Birrhia:
Of him I asked, he said he had not seen you:
It vexed me: still I cast what I should do.
Returning thence, a certain jealousy
By circumstances bred came in my mind.
Umph! here's small roast; the old man sad, a wedding?
It scarce hangs well together.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I buy me straight to hremes; thither come,
I note a silent stillness at the door.
Now, this gave me good heart.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Somewhile I there continue: all that while
I saw no creature passing out or in;
No matron there; no decking of the house;
No stir; I nearer came, and peeped in.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I know they are good conjectures.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Do such things
Think you agree unto a nuptial day?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: In troth I think not Davus.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Do you say, think?
You construe things not well: the case is plain.
Besides, thence going I met Chremes servant
With herbs and small sprats for the old man's supper.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Davus, through thee I am now rid of care.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nay of my faith not so.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Why man prithee?
For thou concludest, he will not give her him.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Conceited pate! as if it therefore followed,
If he not have her, you must marry her.
Unless you looked to't, make your suit, and means
T'her father's friends, you may hap hop wifeless.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thou prompt'st me well; I'll go about it straight.
Though ought this hope have failed me: fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What means my father then?
Why doubles he?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I'll tell you. If he now should chafe at you,
Cause Chremes will not let you have his daughter,
Himself may see he plainly injured you:
If he should press you on, before he knew
How your mind stood inclined to the match.
But if you shall stiffly deny to wed her;
Then he will justly lay the blame on you:
Then shall we have a coil on't.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What wouldst have me
To undergo this marriage?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Pamphilus,
He is your father: and it will be hard
T'oppose him: this your sweet heart too (You know)
Is friendless here. He'll find cause easily
To thrust her out o'th' town.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Counsel me then Davus.
What I should do.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: To be shut out from her, mewed up to this.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: No, no such thing. I guess your father thus
Will say to you: my purpose Pamphilus
Is that this day you wed: then answer you,
Sir, I am ready: pray you tell me now
For what cause can he chide you? by this means
His settled plots you shall disorder clean:
Yourself yet run no hazard; for the thought
Is groundless, vain, that Chremes may be wrought
To give his daughter: nor do you let fall
Your course, lest he his purpose should recall.
Tell you your father that you like the bride:
That, when he would, he have no cause to chide.
And for the dangerous passage that you fear;
I'll steer your course, and waft you over clear.
No man will give his daughter as a wife
To one discovered of your wanton life.
He'll with some poor man rather seek to place her,
Then suffer you to injure or disgrace her.
But if your father see you quiet take
This his command, you shall him reckless make.
At leisure he'll seek out some other wife,
Mean time your father's death may end the strife
Or some like good chance happen.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: There is no doubt ith' world on't.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Take you heed to what you lead me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I'll tell my father as thou bidst me: but
There must be care had, he by no means know
She's with child by me; for I have promised
To give it breeding.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: She begged this promise of me, as assurance
That I would not forsake her.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I'll look to't.
Your father's here: let him not note you sad.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I come to observe their carriage, note their plots.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: He thinks now surely, you'll refuse to marry:
And comes from some lone place premeditate,
Thinking to puzzle you with a set speech:
Therefore collect yourself.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: In this thing Pamphilus you shall take my word,
You shall not now change two cross syllables,
If you but say, you ready are to marry.

div.head: Scen. 5.
div.stage: Enter Byrrhia listening the encounter between Simo and his son.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.l: My master willed me (All things else set of)
Pamphilus watch: and learn what course he takes
About the bride. This caused me dog him hither:
And lo, where he is with Davus. To my task.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Look you back as on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: As I late told thee, 'tis my purpose son
That thou this day be married.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Now I fear
His answer on our side.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Sir, or in this
Or in what else I wait upon your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thou dost now my son
As well becomes thee, when so graciously
Thou yield'st to what I crave.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: My master (As I hear) hath lost his wife.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Get you now in that when the time requires,
We be not driven to stay for you.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.l: That in nothing one man may trust another!
It is an old said saying, and as common,
All to themselves wish best. Myself have seen
The maiden, and remember her a fair one.
Which makes me better bear with Pamphilus,
If he himself had rather nightly bed her,
Then let my master. I'll bear back this news:
That he may pay me well, for my ill tidings.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: My master thinks now I have some device
A foot: and that, for that end I stay here.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I sure did look to hear some news from thee.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I know 'tis chanced quite besides his aim:
That's it which nettles him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Is't possible
I get thee tell me a truth?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Does this same wedding grieve him any thing,
By reason of the acquaintance that he holds
With yonder stranger?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Truly I think not.
Or if it do, the matter of his trouble
Will be at most two or three days' disquiet:
(Conceive you sir?) then it will clearly vanish.
For with himself has ta'en a due account,
And set all clear that way.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Whilst he had leave, and his green youth did suffer't
He wenched a little; but yet privately:
He ever had a care to keep his name
Untouched; as did become a wise young man.
Now marriage fits, he frames his mind that way.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And yet methought he appeared somewhat sad.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Nothing about this business; but there's cause
That makes him somewhat angry with you.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: He says you're overniggardish in cost.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: That you have scarce disbursed ten groats
In your provision for his wedding supper:
What (Says he) is this like a son's nuptials
Whom chiefly of my fellow bachelors
May I invite (Quoth he) to such a banquet?
And to speak that which may be said herein;
Intruth you are too too sparing, I lik't not.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will see
That all shall be well carried. What means this?
What is't this old fox-hunt doth hammer on?
If there be any knavery, his pair forged it.

div.head: Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter lesbia, the midwife and Mysis Glycerium's ma●de at onedsore, Simo and Dauus at another.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: Ay, indeed lesbia you have said aright:
A woman hardly finds a faithful lover.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Belongs this maid to th' Andrian here?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Would either he were dease now or she dumb.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.p: That son or daughter, he will foster it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O Jupiter! what news is this I hear?
All is lost utterly; if she speak truth.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: You do describe a young man honest natured.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: O, the best natured gentleman — but pray,
Follow me in, for fear she stay for you.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: What help for this now, trow?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What, is he mad? A loose land loping strumpet?
Oh! I have it: old dullhead (As I was)
I fierce at length could hit on't.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: What has he hit on, says he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: This first knavish practice
Of my man here is now thus put upon me:
She is to be in child birth, to flight Chremes.
Glycerium within doors. Juno, Lucina help; save me, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Horda such speed? ha, ha, ridiculous
As soon as are she heard me at the door,
The throws come on: scarce fitly a'my word,
You rank and place your times scarce fitly Davus.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Or have your actors missed their cues?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I know not what you mean, sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: If this fellow
Had set upon me, being unprovided
In a true marriage o, what pageants
Would he have played me? Let him now make sure
His own adventure; smsith port secure.

div.head: Scen. 2.
div.stage: Enter lesbia speaking to the nurse within doors.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.l: As yet Archillis I do note in her
All usual matters, and good signs of health
First see her cleansed, and then deliver her
That drink, in measure as I gave in charge:
I'll be here straight again: as God shall help me.
She hath brought Pamphilus a goodly boy.
If it please God, may it live to be a man:
Seeing the father is of disposition
So honest; and makes conscience to wrong
This good young woman.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Who did ever know thee
That would not swear, this thy contriving now?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She cannot in the house give order,
For what is needful to the childbed woman:
But coming forth a doors, proclaims ith' street
Her mind to them within: what? what sir Davus
Slight you me so? or deemest me now at length
Such a fine easy property, thou mayst
So plainly pass thy juggling tricks upon me?
At least yet, it was circumspectly carried;
And showed your awe, if 'twere discovered.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Troth his own cunning cheats him now; not I.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Did I not forewarn thee? threaten further
If thou shouldst dare attempt this? hast thou yet
Stood in fear of't? hath it in ought prevailed?
Thinkest thou I do believe this woman here
Hath had a child now by my Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I now find his mistaking, know my course.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: What talk you of your thinking?
As if y'had had no notice of the matter?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Why good sir, tell me I pray
Found you of yourself that this was counter ?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Come, come, it has been told you:
How else a god's name could you dream of it?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How? 'cause I well did know thy qualities.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: You think it then a thing of my direction.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Truly sir I see
You thoroughly do not know me.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: But when I seek to tell you any thing,
You straight suppose, I put some trick upon you.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: So that I dare scarce speak to you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: This one thing I am sure on; here's no child born.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Are you so sure? yet sir notwithstanding
They straight will lay a child before your door.
I tell you on't aforehand, for your knowledge:
Lest you should say hereafter, Davus plots
And cunning managed all. I very fain
Would work myself out of your jealousy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I have heard so and believe it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: They are many and those grounded circumstances,
Which my conjectures build on. Near before
Named she herself with child by Pamphilus;
And that is false, unless my judgement err:
But seeing now a wedding is preparing,
A midwife straight is sent for, by the maid,
Who was to bring a young born child with her.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Unless you see a child, the wedding still
Stands fairly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I but, sirrah tell me this,
When thou hadst found they plotted this among them, her?
Why told you not it straight to Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Pray, but myself then who hath drawn him from
We know how fondly he did dote upon her:
Now he desires a wife to live withal.
In fine, trust me with this whole business:
Yet pursue you, to make the marriage up;
And I do hope the gods will further it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay, get you in; there see you stay my coming:
And have such things as need in readiness.
He hath not drawn me yet to give full credit
To this he says; nor to conclude all true.
But I regard it little: the main thing
I rest on, is the promise of my son.
I'll now go speak with Chremes, and desire
He would bestow his daughter: that obtained,
Why should I linger? and not now this day
Finish the match a foot? doubtless my son
Will stand t'his word: if not, what hinders me
But I may force him? and in good time see
Where Chremes is, Chremes good time of day.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O! you are the man I sought for.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: You're come as I would wish: a many men
Have pressed unto me; who report as heard
From you, that on this very day your son
Should wed my daughter. Now I come to see
Whether or you or they be from their wits?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Pray list a while, and I will satisfy
This doubt: and withal acquaint you further
What suit I have unto you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I attend.
Say what you please.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Chremes I request you
For love of God; and for the unfeigned friendship
Which in our youth begun along together
Hath grown up with our years; by the respect
You bear your only child; for my son's cause
Chief power of whose preserving lies in you,
Lend me your furtherance in this business,
That the match this day meant may so go on.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Oh! I pray crave it not, as if 't were fit
I should in this thing listen to your suit?
Think you me altered from the man I was,
When late I made you promise? if 't may be
For both our welfares, take my daughter to you
But if hereby more harm then good will follow
To either of us by it, than I pray
Cast for the common good: as if my daughter
Were yours, I father to your Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay, that's my meaning Chremes: and I do
Crave nothing of you but upon such terms:
Nor would I ask it of you, if the case
Itself did not require it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: There's jar between Glycerium and my son.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: So great, I hope't will sunder them.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Indeed
It will just so (As I shall tell thee) prove;
The jars of lovers give fresh life to love.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ay, but I pray you let us prevent that,
Whilst his love's flame is smothered by abuse:
Before this harlots lewd designs, false tears
Reduce his sickly mind to passion,
Let's marry 'em.

sp.speaker: Chremes
sp.l: I have good hope,
Fair wedlock and a wife's experienced love
Will easily pluck him out of these feared ills.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: You think so: but I deem't impossible
That either they will always live together,
Or I may endure their jarring.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How do you know,
Unless you make a trial?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But 'twere hard
For me to make such trial in my child.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Why, all the inconvenience which can happen
Should the worst fall (Which I pray God forbid)
Were at the most a separation.
In counterpoise now weigh the benefits
That will ensue, if my son prove reclaimed:
First you restore to your friend his son: yourself
Gain a fast son in law: your child a husband.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Why, if you think it so commodious,
For my part I will be no hindrance to't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I justly always held you my best friend.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But as to that you said.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Marry how know you
There's now debate between 'em.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Davus self
(Who is their counsels inward secretary)
So told me; and withal advised me further
To haste the marriage with all speed I could.
Think you he would do thus, but that he knows.
My son desires it likewise? you yourself
Shall heat him. Ho there, one call Davus forth.
But lo, I see him coming out a doors.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I was a coming to you.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Why is the bride not sent for? it grows late.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Do you now hear him? I will tell thee Davus,
I lately had thee in some jealousy;
That thou didst take the course most servants hold,
By seeking to delude me in the matter.
Of Pamphilus wanton loving.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I thought so: and for that I kept from you
A secret, I'll now utter.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll tell thee; for I almost now do trust thee.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: At length you find what servant you have of me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: This was not to have been a marriage

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: But I therefore counterfeited,
That I might feel your minds.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: La ye; I could never,
Think such a matter: o fine cunning plot?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: List this; when hence I bade thee get thee in,
Chremes came fitly to me.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Are we trow
Not lost for ever?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I told all to him
Thou late toldst me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Begged of him,
And scarce at length won him to give his daughter.

sp.speaker: Chre.
sp.l: I'll straight get me home,
And leave word all be had in readiness!
Thence give you notice.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now I prithee Davus,
Since thou alone hast wrought this marriage for us —

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Yes sure, I was th'only worker.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Do now
Endeavour further to reclaim my son.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Yes truly, I will look to't carefully.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou mayst now do it, whilst his mind is vexed.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Look to't then:
But where now is he himself?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll too him then, and to himself deliver
All I told thee.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I am now just nothing. Exit Simo.
What hinders, but I fairly take my way
Directly to the mill, and fall a grinding?
Entreaty may do nothing; I have drawn
All things to such confusion: first deceived
My master: then have headlong thrust his son
Upon a marriage, that he looked not for:
And clean against his will: and this today
To be made up, by my alone procurement.
Pray mark th'end of cunning: had I sat still,
No evil in the world had happened.
And see where he is. I am a mere dead man.
Would I had any means to break my neck now.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Where is the villain has undone me?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: But I confess
'Tis justly fallen upon me; since I am
So idle, vain, and inconsiderate:
Ought I to trust my whole state to a slave;
A prating slave? I have my folly's hire:
But unrevenged he ne'er shall scape with it.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I'll ne'er doubt tempest, if I scape this storm.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: But now what answer shall I make my father?
Shall I deny to marry, who but now
Consented to it? with what impudence
May I dare do it? neither with myself
Know I what course to take.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Troth nor I, neither
But I am canvassing my brains about it.
I'll tell him I'll forthwith find out some means
A little to put off his threatened vengeance.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: O, you sir, honest fellow
Come nearer: what sayest to me? do you see now
How I am puzzled through your goodly counsel?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Trust thee pillory?
Or thou make good a case perplexed, lost?
See what a suresby I have trusted too;
Who from a quiet state I late stood in,
This day hast thrust me on a marriage:
Did I not tell thee it would thus fall out?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Hanging.
A little yet let me collect myself.
I'll straight find out some help.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: O me accursed:
Why want I time to plague thee as I would?
This scarce will serve my danger to prevent,
Permits me not pursue thy punishment.

div.head: Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Charinus at one door; Pamphilus and Dauus at another.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: May't be believed? or may it once be talked on?
That any should be so self-willed perverse,
As to take pleasure in another's harms?
Or think his own gain sweeter, if procured
By others disadvantage? o good God!
Is this a brood of men? Men let them be;
Worst are they of the generation.
They show a little tricksy modesty,
Not to deny a craved courtesy:
But when performance comes, they then declare
(Nature will show itself) what men they are.
They are ashamed a little, but in trial
Their temper bursteth forth to flat denial.
Then shall you hear their shameless oratory —
Pray who are you? are what at least to me.
Why yield my love to you? good sir attend,
I am unto myself the nearest friend.
Touch them with faith and troth, they blush no whit:
So that when no constraint enforceth it,
They make some scruple; when it comes to th' pinch,
Then at the proof your hollow friend doth flinch.
But what's my best course? shall I to him straight,
And with him this his wrong expostulate?
And ply him with harsh terms? but some may say,
What good shall I procure myself that way?
Yes much: I shall both chafe him, and give ease
To my grieved heart.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Charinus, less god please
To succour us, I have both thee and me
Against my will undone unwarily.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Unwarily: is that word now thought on?
You've broke your promisd faith.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Seek you again with fair words to abuse me?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: After I said I loved her,
You must needs like her too. O me accursed,
That scantled out your dealing by mine own!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Seemed your content not full,
Unless you fooled, and with false hope trained on
A wretched lover? much good do ye; take her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I take her? o I perceive thou knowest not
In what a gulf of misery I am plunged:
What peck of troubles this my torturer
Hath brought me to, by harkening to his counsel.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: No mar'le: he takes his precedent from you.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: You would not say this, if you fully knew
Or me, or her I've set my fancy on.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Yes, I do know; you were at hot high words
Late with your father; and have angered him,
Because he cannot make you marry her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Nay, which discovers thou less knowest my grief,
This marriage never was prepared for me:
Nor did now any force me to a wife.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I know't your own will forced you.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Tarry, yet thou knowest not all.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Why do you thus torment me? hear but this
He never ceased to be urgent on me,
That I should tell my father I would marry:
To entreat, persuade, till he had drawn me to it.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Davus brings all things out of square.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I nothing know, except this one thing only,
That I well see the gods are much displeased
With me, for listening to him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Ha, what fairest thou caitiff?
The gods give thee a death fitting thy doings.
Sir than, but tell me; say that all his foes
Had laid their heads together for a plot
To yoke him to a wife, what stratagem
Could they have framed more speeding than this was?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I am deceived, but faint not.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: It thrived not this way, we'll attempt some other.
Unless you judge because at first we sped not,
There's no means jest us to salve up the mischief.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Nay more, I well believe if thou watch for it,
Of one thou'lt make me out a double marriage.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I (Pamphilus) by reason of my bondage
Owe you thus much: to do, go, night and day
To endeavour all I may, with my life's hazard,
For your advantage: it is yet your part
To bear with me, if things come cross my hopes:
My plots fail; yet I use all carefulness:
Yourself else frame things wiseher, discharge me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I crave thou leave me in that state thou foundst me;

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: How now! hist, stay.
Glycerium's door did creak.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: But I will give't you fashioned presently.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: Where ere he be, I'll find your Pamphilus
And bring him with me straight;
Meanwhile good heart vex not yourself.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: What's the matter?
O, was't you Pamphilus? you are well met.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: My mistress prays you of all love
To come to her: she longs to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I am a forlorn wretch: the mischief spreads.
That she and I should both be thus perplexed
By means of thee? for I am therefore sent for
Because she hears my wedding is prepared.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: From which how easily had you now been quiet,
Had he been quiet?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Yes, so, go on:
If of himself he be not vexed enough,
Urge him on further.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: I indeed 'tis that
Does now afflict her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Mysis, I do swear
By all the gods unto thee, I will never
Forsake her: no, though I were sure thereby
To undergo the whole world's enmity.
I did desire her; have obtained her; see
That we both jump in minds, and quality.
Farewell to all that seek us two to sever:
But death none takes her from me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I do desire (If't may be so born up)
My father should not think I am the cause
The marriage holds not: if that cannot be,
I'll take the next course: that he may perceive
I cross it. What kind of man dost think me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Faith every way as wretched as myself.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ay, thou hast a good heart.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: And will effect it for you.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: You mistake;
It is for him, not you.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I have scarce day enough
To finish it I fear: and think me not
At leisure therefore now, to tell you it.
But get y'hence both; you, now but hinder me.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: And you, whither you? Exit Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Wilt thou I tell thee truth?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nay see, he makes a prologue to a tale.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: O impudent! is't not enough I give thee
Some hours; by putting off his marriage?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Yet if thou canst do ought —
Come home to me.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: To what end should I come?
I nothing have to help thee.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If thou canst think of ought
I'll be at home.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Mysis, while I go hence
Stay here a little for me.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I will be here straightway again with thee.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: That no one holdeth any thing in certain?
Your help good gods! I thought this Pamphilus
Had been my mistress's firm, chiefest good;
Took him to be her friend, her lover, husband;
Ready at all essays to stand to her:
And yet what grief sustains she now through him?
Hence sure more ill she reaps then good from him.
But here comes Davus.
What's that prithee friend? the child?
Whither dost bear it?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Mysis, now I
Need thy readrest memory and wit
In this I go about.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Take the child from me straight, and lay it down
Before our door.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.p: What on the bare ground pray?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Take a few strewings from the altar there —
And lay 'em under.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: That if perchance my master urge my oath
'Twas not my doing, I may safely swear it.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: I understand you: but pray tell me whence
This now new tender conscience comes upon thee?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Stir you more quick; that you may further know
What 'tis I have in hand. O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: The father of the bride is come on us. Leave the course which I at first intended.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.p: I know not what you talk on?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Myself too
Will make as if I came from the right hand.
Have you a care now as occasion serves
You mark my talk, and suit your words to mine.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: I understand nothing you go about:
But if in any thing you need my help
Or see more than myself, I here will stay,
That I may be no hindrance in your way.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Having prepared all in readiness
Was needful to my daughter's marriage,
I now return to will 'em send for her.
But what is here? so help me God, a child!
Woman, laid you this child here?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: Woes me, out of sight.
Alas, Davus has left me: and is gone. Enter Dauus.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Faith of the gods!
What coil's yond at the market?
What throng of wranglers brawl there? and beside
Corn bears excessive price. I know not now
What other words to use.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: For god's sake man
Why left you me alone here?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Hoida what
Denice is this? you Mysis, whence this child?
Or who here laid it?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: Are you in your wits,
To ask me that?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Of whom else should I ask,
That see none else here?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Look thou beware
Thou utter not a word, but what I ask thee.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: From whence is it? speak out.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he, is't news, if women
Of your condition do grow impudent?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This maid belongs to th' Andrian, as I think.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Seem we such fitting persons to you, trow
That you should play on us?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Therefore with speed take you the child away
Ilence from our door: yet stay, see thou stir not
One inch out of this place.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: The gods confound thee
That me poor woman frightest thus.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Do I speak to thee, or not?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Asked thou still?
Say, tell me whose child 'tis thou hast laid here?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Talk not of what I know,
But tell me that I ask.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I always rightly shunned this match.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Which child did not myself see yesternight
Brought late to you?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: 'Tis truth, I saw Canthara thick stuffed out.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: I thank the gods yet, that some city wives
Were present at the labour.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: She not knows
Him (I assure thee) for whose cause she plots this.
She thinks if Chremes see a child laid here,
He'll not bestow his daughter: yes of truth,
For this the rather.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Faith but he will not though.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Now therefore, for thy knowledge, take it hence
Or I will tumble it in the high way;
And further lay thee by it in the kennel.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: One cunning prank
Treads on another's he'll. I hear it whispered
She's a freeborn Athenian.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: And that
He shall be forced by law to marry her.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.p: Why sir I pray you, is she not freeborn?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I had almost unawares jested myself
Into a dangerous mischief.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Who talks here?
O Chremes you are come in happy time.
Pray listen sir —

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Have you pray heard it? see their villainies!
'Tis fit she were hence hurried to the rack.
This is the man I talked of: do not think
You play your tricks on Davus.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: O wretched me!
Indeed (Good old sir) I have spoke no falsehood.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I know all to the full: but is your master
Simo within?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: Rogue hand me not.
Troth if Glycerium know not of all this —

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Attend you fool, thou knowest not what is done:
This the bride's father: by no other means
Could he be made to know what we would have him.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.p: Why then you should have told me on't.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Dost think
There no great difference, when a thing is carried
The natural way, and when premeditate.

div.head: Scen. 6.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: 'Tis told me Chrysis dwelled in this same street:
Who rather chose here lewdly to grow rich,
Then in her country honestly live poor:
She dead, the law hath cast her state on me.
But now I see some I may question:
God save you.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: O good God whom do I see?
Is not this Crito, Chrisis' cousin germane?
'Tis he.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: O Mysis! you are well met.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: The gods
Prosper you Crito.

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.p: Yes truly she has left us, to th'wide world.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: And you, what shift d'ye make? any thing well?

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.l: We? faith e'en according to the proverb;
Live as we can, since cannot as we would.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: Glycerium — what, hath she yet sound her parents?

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: What not yet? I came hither
In an unlucky hour: for had I known it
I sure would ne'er have stirred a soot this way.
She always was both said and deemed her sister
And holds all that was hers: now for me their
To follow law suits being here a stranger,
How easy and commodious 'tmay be
Rife precedents of other men do warn me.
Besides, I judge by this she has got herself
Some friend and patron: for when she came thence
She had well-near attained to ripe years
Men will cry out I am a sycophant,
A beggar laying claim to others right:
Withal, myself list not impoverish her:

sp.speaker: Mys.
sp.p: Good Crito, you still hood your ancient course.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: Bring me unto her, since I am come hither,
I may at least yet see her.

sp.speaker: Dau
sp.p: I'll follow yet the old man shall not see me.

div.p: Mysis and Crito enter Glycerium's house and Davus follows them.

div.head: Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Chremes and Simo out of Simoes' house.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Simo enough, I have enough tried your friend ship:
Ventured sufficient hazard, pray now leave
Entreating. Whilst I seek to pleasure you
I almost trifled my child's life away.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay, but I earnestly beg and crave Chremes,
This your good turn now late begun in words
You would in deeds make up.

sp.speaker: Chr
sp.l: Note how unjust
You grow, through earnestness to work your aims:
You nor consider bounds in courtesies,
Nor yet what 'tis you crame: for if you did,
You'd cease to load me with these injuries.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: O, do you question them?
You wrought me to bestow my only child
To one entangled in a stranger's love:
A wild young youth abhorring marriage:
To most sure discord, marriage as insure;
That by her grief and sorrow I might physic
Your riotous son: this y'obtained: I went on,
Whilst things permitted: now that the case not brooks it,
You must brook my denial. 'tis affirmed
This stranger is fice born; hath a child by him:
Leave troubling us.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By all the gods I beg
You would not bend your mind to trust these people,
Whose best advantage 'tis, to make him worst.
These things are only feigned and fashioned
To dash the wedding: take away the cause
Moves them to this, they'll straight weigh leave contrining.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: You're wide: myself saw a maid scolding here
With Davus.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I but this was done
In good sad earnest; neither of them both
Knowing that I was near.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I do believe it
And Davus late told me it would be so.
I know not how I did forget to tell you,
As I had meant.

div.head: Scen. 2.
div.stage: Enter. Dauus out of Glycerium's house.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I will you now rest quiet —

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Through my furtherance and this guests.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Man, time, coming fitter, I never saw.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Who is't, the rogue so praises?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Cease I to speak to him?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: O Simo, o our Chremes,
All things are now in readiness within.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: When you please, send for her.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis very well; but that course now here fails us.
But may I know, what thou hadst there to do?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: As if I ask 't thee, when?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Is my son there?
I wretch am set o'th rack. Didst not hangman
Tell me, they were at deadly odds together?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: He? what thinkst?
I warrant railing at her.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Nay but Chremes
I'll tell you now of a strange accident.
I know not what old man is newly come,
Note him, a man both confident and wise,
When you shall see him, you'll much value him.
A grave austerity rests on his face;
And in his words dwell faith.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: No other, than I heard that man report.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: That he does know
Glycerium here, a free Athenian born.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If thou speakest one word more — Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I do beseech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Hoist in this fellow here, hence speedily.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: For it is my pleasure.
Away with him I say.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: If you shall find I have lied
In any thing, then kill me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll hear nothing.
I'll straightway put thee into motion.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Though that I said the truth?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Though — see you
I'll be kept bound; and hear you, bound all four.
I'll show thee, what 'tis to abuse a master,
If I but live this day: and teach the other
What 'tis to cross a father.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O, I pray you rage not so much.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Chremes dost not, seeing
How unkindly he deals with me, pity me?
That I should toil and care for such a son?
But Pamphitus you, come you out Pamphilus:
Doth any shame possess thee?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Who called me?
I am lost, it is my father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What sayest now?
Thou of all —

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: O, rather go to th'point man:
And spare ill speaking.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: As if any thing
Can be spoke ill enough of such a one?
But sirrah say, is your Glycerium now
Free born of Athens?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Do they say so? Monstrous audaciousness!
Considers he his words? grieves at his deeds?
Or shows his colour any note of shame?
That he should be of such debauched manners,
That clear beyond all precedent of freemen,
Against the form of law, in opposition
Of me his father, he should bend to have her
Though 't reach to th'highest pitch of infamy?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Dost thou now at length
Perceive that Pamphilus? that word of old
Of old that word then truly fitted thee,
When first thou setst thy heart to please thyself;
Though at what rate soever compassed.
But wherefore do I thus? why yex my soul?
Why waste myself away? why do I grieve
My old and fainting age with his youth's follies?
Shall I endure the penance of his faultings?
No, let him have her; ay, God speed him well;
Yes, let him keep with her.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Why callest me father? as if thou hadst need
Of me to be thy father? A house, wise,
Children are had maugre thy father's will:
Fellows are hired shall bear her up freeborn.
You've got the mast'tie.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I beseech you father,
May I have leave to utter a few words.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I hear him: what is't Chremes I should hear him.

sp.speaker: Pam
sp.l: I do confess I love this woman here
If it be faulty, I confess that too.
Further I yield me up to your full pleasure,
Lay any task, any command upon me.
Will you I marry that, leave this? I will
Endure it as I may. But this one thing
I beg of you, that you would not imagine
That this old man is by my means brought in
Suffer me clear myself, and fetch him hither
Into your presence

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He craves but reason, grant it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well, I do: I wish Chremes ought be proved,
So that I find he does not juggle with me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Slight accusation in a son's offence
Sufficeth for a father.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: Cease to entreat.
Each of the reasons you have used, persuade me
To your request? either your own self cause,
Or for it is a truth, or cause I wish
All furtherance unto Gl

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Do I not see Crito of Andros there?
'Tis he. Crito you are here well met:
You have been long a stranger here: what chance
Hath brought you now to Athens.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: An occasion.
But is this Simo?

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Ask you for me?
D'ye hear sir, is it you that do affirm
Glycerium to be free born of Athens?

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: Are you one, do deny it?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Is 't e'en so?
Come you so well prepared too?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Dost thou use question? thinkst thou to escape
Fairly thus of with 't? seekest thou to work on
The easy natures of unguided youth,
Perverting our well nurtured children?
Winning their hearts with fawning promises.
And this, in Athens.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And harlot-loves knit'st up in marriage?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: If you knew this man Simo thoroughly,
You would not judge so: he is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: An honest man; to come jump in th'instant
Of dosing hands, and never seen here before?
Chremes, may such a man be credited?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: If I not doubted to displease my father
I easily could prompt him to that point.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Forbear Crito;
It is his temper.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: Let him regard his temper:
If he will vent his pleasure upon me
He shall be forced to hear what will displease him.
Trouble I his matters? or yet care for 'em?
Cannot you bear your own ills patiently?
For my part, it may instantly be known
Whether 't be false or true, you heard me say
A certain man of Athens, now long since
Shipwrecked at sea, was cast on Andros isle;
And with him this Glycerium, than a child:
He being poor had harbour at the house
Of Chrisis , father.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: Does he disturb me thus?
He that entertained him was my kinsman:
Of him I then heard, that this shipwrecked man
Was an Ithenian.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: His name so suddenly? Pha — Pha-nia.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: Yes sure, I think 'twas Phania.
This I well know, he named himself of Ramnes.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: A many more in Andros
Then heard it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I beseech the gods, it prove
According to my hopes: but pray you Crito,
What said he of the child, that 'twas his own?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I knew him well, and know that he was so.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: He flying hence to avoid the rage of war,
Travailed towards Asia in pursuit of me;
And feared withal to leave the child behind:
Since whence, now I hear the first news of him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I scarcely feel myself: my mind's so tossed
Twixt fear, and hope, and joy, and wondering,
At this so great, so sudden happiness.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: In truth I much rejoice, she is found yours.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I do believe you father.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: But there rests
One scruple yet, which somewhat troubles me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You are worthy now of hate, with these your scruples

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.l: She had sure
Another being young.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: What was it Crito?
Canst thou remember?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Shall I permit his tardy memory
To slacken my joy's current, being able
Herein to give myself a remedy?
No, I will not: hark you hither Chremes;
The name you doubt of is Pasibula.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I heard it of herself
At lest a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I believe Chremes,
You think we all joy at it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: As may the gods
Assist me, I do think so.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The case itself now reconcileth us.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: O my most loving father and you Chromes
Change nothing in the wife I now possess?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: The cause is just, your father so agreeing.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Her dowry Pamphilus I make ten talents.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I'll forthwith see my daughter: Crito, pray
Go with me; for I think she knows me not.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why cause you not your wife be brought to us?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You warn me well, I'll e'en give Davus charge out.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Has more and greater charge upon himself.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No; I did will him be bound otherwise.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll in and see it done.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: O happy, o this prosperous blessed day.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I come to see how Pampirlus speeds, and lo.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Some man perhaps may think I feed on dreams:
But now I please to think all real truth.
I on this ground judge the god's lives eternal,
Because heir pleasure's certainly their own
For I myself have gained immortal state,
If with this joy no grief ere intermeddle
But who might I now wish especially
Here at this time, to tell the tidings to?

sp.speaker: Chae.
sp.p: What joy is that he talks of?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I now see
Davus our man: there is no living one,
I rather would have had. I know he will?
Full truly joy in the true joy I feel.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Thou knowest not what has befallen me?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: True: yet know, what has chanced me.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Why this haps just oth' fashion,
That you my ill luck learn, ere I your good.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Glycerium hath found out her parents.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Nor now is any stay,
But that I take her home forthwith to wife.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Dreams he trow, of things he desires waking?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Leave of I pray:
The gods sure purpose him their minion.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I am a made man, if these things be true
I'll speak to 'em.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: O Charinus,
Thou comest in a fit time.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Yes all: pray think on me,
Now in the height of your felicity.
Chremes is now your own, and I do know
He'll yield to any thing you motion.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I mind it. But 't would now be overlong
Here to attend, till he come forth to us.
Follow me in; he's with Glycerium.
Get you home Davus, hasten; and procure
Some that may bear her hence: why standest thou so?
Why stayest thou still?

div.head: Epilogue by Davus. Addition, by way of paraphrase on Davus last words in the scene.
div.l: I note you sit with kind attention bent,
As pleased with what hath passed; and expect
The further issue of our argument;
And on the marriage now your minds reflect.
We pray you cease such expectation;
For we have done: the bride you do conceive
But newly brought to bed; night coming on
Women shall bear her hence, at Siono's leave.
Chremes his younger daughter Philumen
Charinus gets, at sure of Pamphilus.
Crito of Andros, who has been the mean
The long lost child should be discovered thus,
What course he now shall take to obtain his right
In Chrysis goods, I here not mention will;
Nor in indeed can I: I have no insight
In law points, triable at Mars his hill.
Yet knowing Chremes nature tractable,
Seeing withal he hath dealt liberally
In portion, so that amph lus is able
To bear the loss, though-common honesty
Did not exact it I not doubt they will
Use the poor stranger well. Me you have scene heis
Venture to binding, grinding in the mill:
That fell on me, this was approaching near.
I purpose further in their joy to sue
My present freedom: Pamphilus love I have,
Glyceriums also; both I think of due:
My master's chase is off I only crave
Your furtherance in the matter; which if gained,
I have good hope: for I have heard it said
By men ith' Periclean laws well read,
If I make you my friends, my suit's obtained:
For they have told me my discharge now stands
Not upon whispering voices; but clapped hands.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
